description: The Holy Trinity Cathedral, known locally as Sameba, is the largest cathedral in Georgia and the third-tallest Eastern Orthodox cathedral in the world. Standing at 101 meters high on Elia Hill overlooking the Kura River, this architectural masterpiece combines traditional Georgian church styles with Byzantine elements. Constructed between 1995 and 2004, it was built to commemorate 1,500 years of autocephaly of the Georgian Orthodox Church and 2,000 years from the birth of Jesus. The cathedral's massive golden dome, covered with one ton of gold and crowned by an 8.1-meter high cross, dominates Tbilisi's skyline. The complex can accommodate up to 15,000 people and includes nine chapels (five underground), a free-standing bell tower, the Patriarch's residence, a monastery, clerical seminary, and theological academy.
highlights: Third-tallest Eastern Orthodox cathedral globally, reaching 101 meters to the cross tip
Massive golden dome covered with one ton of gold, visible across Tbilisi
Stunning interior frescoes and mosaics created by prominent Georgian artists under supervision of icon painter Amiran Goglidze
Catholicos Patriarch Ilia II personally painted several icons including a large image of the Holy Virgin at the entrance
Nine chapels including the Archangels, John the Baptist, Saint Nino, Saint George, Saint Nicholas, the Twelve Apostles, and All Saints
Five underground chapels within the lower level compartment
Synthesis of traditional Georgian architectural styles from various historical periods with Byzantine undertones
Panoramic views of downtown Tbilisi from the cathedral complex grounds
Symbol of Georgian national and spiritual revival after Soviet era
Built entirely through anonymous donations from businessmen and common citizens
Consecrated on St. George's Day, November 23, 2004, by Patriarch Ilia II with representatives from Orthodox Churches worldwide
tips: Opening hours: Daily from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM, with typical visiting hours 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM
Dress code strictly enforced: Women must wear long skirts/pants covering knees, tops covering shoulders, and head scarves (available at entrance)
Men should not wear shorts or hats inside the cathedral
No entrance fee - the cathedral and grounds are free to visit
Photography rules: Check current signage as recent signs prohibit photography inside; always be respectful during services
Best times to visit: Early morning or sunset for optimal lighting and fewer crowds; blue hour in winter offers stunning skyline views
Steep steps lead up to the cathedral, but vehicle access road available for those with mobility concerns
Weekend liturgies and choirs typically at 9:00 AM - arrive early to witness Orthodox ceremonies
Allow 1-2 hours to fully explore the cathedral interior, underground chapels, and complex grounds
Borrow head scarves from the entrance if needed - usually available for women visitors
Be respectful during active worship services and ceremonies, which are open to the public
Visit the surrounding complex grounds for workshops and rest areas with excellent city views
vibe: Majestic and spiritually profound, the Holy Trinity Cathedral emanates an atmosphere of national pride and religious reverence. The soaring golden dome creates a sense of awe even before entering, while the interior transports visitors into a realm of sacred art and Byzantine grandeur. Intricate frescoes covering every surface, the scent of incense, and the acoustics of Orthodox chanting during services create a deeply moving experience. As a symbol of Georgia's post-Soviet religious revival and cultural resilience, Sameba carries profound emotional significance for Georgians. The cathedral balances its role as an active house of worship with welcoming tourism, offering both spiritual seekers and architecture enthusiasts an unforgettable encounter with Georgian Orthodox tradition and contemporary religious art. The peaceful grounds provide contemplative spaces with sweeping views over Tbilisi, making it both a cultural landmark and a sanctuary above the bustling city.
